visuals.title: Fireflies Synchronization
visuals.description:
This is a Processing sketch to simulate the way fireflies synchronize with one another. Each of of the circles represents a single firefly and when another firefly on the screen flashes white, or "fires", the firefly will try and catch up to the firefly that just fired. The world makes many assumptions, so here is a list of some of them:
1) Every firefly can see every other firefly and has 20/20 vision
2) Every firefly starts with the same period
3) Every firefly is influenced additively or linearly by the number of flies firing

visuals.title: Tiny Fibonacci Sphere v2.0
visuals.description:
A fast method of producing an arbitrary number of equally distributed points around a sphere. This is accomplished by drawing a fibonacci spiral (similar to sunflower seed pattern) that maintains constant surface area.

n = number of points
phi = (sqrt(5)+1)/2 - 1
ga = PHI * PI

for each point i (1..n)
longitude = ga*i
latitude = asin(-1 + 2*i/n)

As written, the sketch constantly adds new points to the sphere. Click to toggle this feature, so you can examine the point distribution.

visuals.title: Camera motion to MSA
visuals.description:
-Detect motion/flow from webcam and plug it unto MSA fluid, 
-Renders it back mirrored. 
-Awesome.
-Webkit browsers only.
-Requires a decent machine!
-Will not compile or run in PDE! (due to the way the webcam code works)

Check my profile for a high resolution version! (it's a tweak of this one)
visuals.instructions: Open in a Webkit browser like Chrome / Safari. Turn your webcam on. Wave your hand, turn your head

visuals.title: visualization of 2d perlin noise by lines
Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: 3D Plotter
visuals.description: A way to plot 3D graphs in the form "y = f(x) +f(z)".
visuals.instructions:
Mouse to look around. Box changes y-scale, UP arrow to "zoom in", DOWN arrow to "zoom out".

Note: you can use "x^2", but for nested powers use "pow(x^2, 2)". You can also use certain parts of programming, use "fc" for "frameCount" to make the sketches dynamic.

visuals.title: Perlin Noise - Capozzo
visuals.description:
Alessandro Capozzo did some fantastic processing sketches when processing was in its infancy. I thought it would be good to examine some of the code and rewrite it for Processing 2. This sketch looks at Perlin Noise. Its really simple however I think this would be a cool piece to go along a large wall.

You can find more about me at 
http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~keving/

Alessandro Capozzo is at
http://www.abstract-codex.net

visuals.title: Perlin Noise - Capozzo

Alessandro Capozzo did some fantastic processing sketches when processing was in its infancy. I thought it would be good to examine some of the code and rewrite it for Processing 2. This sketch looks at Perlin Noise. Its really simple however I think this would be a cool piece to go along a large wall.

You can find more about me at 
http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~keving/

Alessandro Capozzo is at
http://www.abstract-codex.net

visuals.title: Recursive Tree
visuals.description:
Since everybody got one: Here is my version of a recursive Tree. The text you see at the bottom of the sketch is the seed value for the random generator. Change the seed and see what happens.

Controls:
- TYPE SOMETHING = create seed
- MOUSECLICK = create random seed and generate tree
- BACKSPACE/DEL = delete last letter
- RETURN/ENTER/CTRL = confirm your seed and generate tree
- ALT = save image

visuals.title: Interactive Roots
visuals.description:
I saw Ian Dixon's "Roots" and was inspired to make this.
This is built from the ground up, with a pile of user commands!

So, the commands (click the applet before trying these):
Blank screen: b
Toggle Colors: c
Toggle outlines: o
Toggle Transparency: t
Toggle infinite drawing: i
Circular (polar) boundary: p
Rectangular boundary: r
Toggle growth/shrinkage: s
Reset: spacebar
Faster, Slower: +, =
More, Less turns: _, -
Larger, Smaller: {, [
More, Less roots: }, ]

visuals.title: Random palette generator
visuals.description:
A tweak of my last sketch in which I used random colors, but selected random limits in order to get something not too random, with colors that go well together.

It resulted in some interesting palettes so I decided to do something that allows me to see which values produce these colors and experiment with different values.

Mouse over the pattern will show the red, green and blue parameters of the color.
Mouse click over the pattern will load a new one with the same rule.
Click on Random to reload with random rules.
Click on Run to reload with the rules selected with the sliders.

visuals.title: Webcam Shader
visuals.description:
Creates a fantasy image from your webcam's input using a custom shader.
Example found at https://p5js.org/examples/3d-shader-using-webcam.html
The two shader files had to be renamed, since OpenProcessing would not upload them as 'webcam.vert' and 'webcam.frag'. I renamed them as text files and then they uploaded and worked fine! - Richard Bourne
visuals.instructions: Tap the mouse or screen to save the full screen on a new tab. It will be upside down. Press and hold on the image to get the popup menu and select Save Image. Then in Photos, choose Edit and rotate the image right way up.

visuals.title: Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: Gears&Backlashes_1.0
visuals.description:
ガタガタ歯車。by KaijinQ .
Gears that mesh and turn realistically. They also show backlash (slack) when the red driver gear reverses direction. The more gears you draw, the more delay there is before a change of driver direction reaches the last gear drawn.
Colored gears and image save by Richard Bourne.
visuals.instructions:
Tap mouse or finger where you want to place a new gear. 
Hint: the gear will be drawn at a size that meshes with the previous gear.
Continue until you have drawn as many gears as desired.
Press any key to save an image.

visuals.title: Draw generative neurons using Poisson process
visuals.description:
A lthough a neuron's firing rate is often communicated as regularly spaced events which occur at a changing rate, this is a convenient oversimplification. In computational neuroscience, the timing of individual action potentials  is  often described mathematically as an inhomogenous Poisson process - wherein the time between subsequent firing events follow an exponential frequency distribution.
In this graphic, I attempt to capture this statistical irregularity, by drawing each neuron according to a Poisson process.

visuals.title: Multi Gravity Planets and Sun
visuals.description:
System which tends to stabilize itself, the more particles you add the more complex orbital system you will probably observe.

Red dot marks a center of gravity of all computed particles. When it starts creating some patterns, the system is very close to stadium of self-stabilization (synchronized cycles).

10+ particles takes often hours (if not forever) to create any *visible* patterns..

**(it is to consider, in which scale we call things already patterns by giving them any name)

visuals.title: Obj viewer
visuals.description:
Reads data from an obj format and displays it.

An obj format is a generic format used by most 3d software packages to describe a mesh. In fact, this model was exported out from Maya.

There's so much more to be done with this, but here's a start!

Controls:
    - Drag left-click to rotate camera.
    - Drag middle-click to move camera.
    - Drag right-click to zoom.
    - E to toggle edges.
    - P to toggle points.
    - F to toggle faces.

visuals.title: Lightning Storm
visuals.description:
It's a storm!
For an instant strike, click the mouse on the applet
To turn on/off storm mode, hit 's'
To make the bolts come faster/slower, hit '-','='
To disable/enable fading, hit 'f'
For random colors, hit 'c'
And for yellow, hit 'c' again
To clear the screen, hit spacebar
To reset it, hit 'r'

visuals.title: Written Circles
visuals.description:
New image every 10 seconds.
Written Circles is generative artwork for Written Images: a project in contemporary generative print design and art. Its final products will be a book that presents. programmed images by various artists. Each print in process will be calculated individually – which makes every single book unique. High resolutions images at http://www.flickr.com/photos/paolotonon/sets/72157623864535761/

visuals.description:
Since everybody got one: Here is my version of a recursive Tree. The text you see at the bottom of the sketch is the seed value for the random generator. Change the seed and see what happens.

Controls:
- TYPE SOMETHING = create seed
- MOUSECLICK = create random seed and generate tree
- BACKSPACE/DEL = delete last letter
- RETURN/ENTER/CTRL = confirm your seed and generate tree
- ALT = save image

visuals.title: rescued from oblivion: Feathers
visuals.description:
openprocessing.org has thousands of sketches that have been marked "Archived Sketch: This sketch is created  with an older version of Processing, and doesn't work on browsers anymore." Most of them work fine, or do so after editing a single line. Some of them - like this one - deserve to be rescued from oblivion.

Original description:

Generates random feathers based on user's mouse click. Feathers created closer to the left are more organized "flight" feathers, whereas feathers created on the right side are more disorganized "downy" feathers.

visuals.title: Delaunay Subdivision
visuals.description:
(unoptimized) Delaunay triangulation with various display modes.
The graphic starts with two triangles. Each frame new triangles are added. The new triangles are made from a subdivision of one existing triangle - one triangle is subdivided into three new triangles. The triangle who gets subdivided is choosen at random.  Delaunay triangulation implementation done from scratch. See code for references.
visuals.instructions: Press mouse to switch between display modes. Press any key for new graphic.

visuals.title: Islamic Stars
visuals.description:
Move the mouse horizontally and vertically to change the image.  X and Y control two different parameters.

This was an experiment with a method used to produce Arabic/Islamic star tiling patterns, from an underlying grid of polygons.

Starting with an underlying grid of polygons, the star pattern is produced by drawing lines from two equidistant points on each polygon edge at some fixed angle (controlled by the mouse).  At the point where the lines would intersect with other lines, they are clipped.

Y controls the distance from the center of the polygon edge.
X controls angle.

visuals.title: EEG-FLOW
visuals.description:
We see the envelope of multiple oscillations from the human resting state EEG during eyes closed. A chunk of 20 sec is plotted clockwise circularly along the outer edge The time series shrinks, changes color and slowly starts to oscillate tangentially as it gets attracted towards the center of the circle, leaving behind multiple traces of itself. A pulsating, hypnotic figure emerges, reminiscent of a sea urchin or a flower

Move mouse towards right-left edge to shrink-grow shape.
move mouse vertically to increase the amplitude of the oscillation of the tangential rotation.
Click to reset

visuals.title: Biomorpha Europensis
visuals.description: Biomorphs are strange and eerily biological-looking complex number fractal forms of startling variety. The simplest look like primitive monocellular blobs with infinitely descending internal contours, some of which openly betray their algorithmic relation to the Fatou-Julia sets through their dragon-like spirals. While others display remarkably complex structures ranging from microbiological-looking forms reminiscent of Hooke's radiolaria to exotic floral shapes: inveritable microbes from the complex plane.
visuals.instructions: Click to toggle interactive mode, where the mouse cursor's position defines the biomorph's seed.

visuals.title: Rorschach Generator
visuals.description:
To see how this works, hit 'f' to disable the filter. You'll see that the balls are darkest at the center and lightest at the outside. The filter gets rid of everything lighter than the threshold, and turns everything else black. 


controls:
Various modes of motion: 1-7
Reset everything: z
Toggle Rorschach mode: r
Cycle through shapes: s
Invert shape: i
Invert colors toggle: b
Random/BW color switch: c
Pause motion: p
Filter toggle: f
Discrete/Continuous: d

Change number of balls: _,+
Change radius: -,=
Change discretization steps: {,}
Adjust threshold: [,]

visuals.title: Biomorpha Europensis
visuals.description: Biomorphs are strange and eerily biological-looking complex number fractal forms of startling variety. The simplest look like primitive monocellular blobs with infinitely descending internal contours, some of which openly betray their algorithmic relation to the Fatou-Julia sets through their dragon-like spirals. While others display remarkably complex structures ranging from microbiological-looking forms reminiscent of Hooke's radiolaria to exotic floral shapes: inveritable microbes from the complex plane.
visuals.instructions: Click to toggle interactive mode, where the mouse cursor's position defines the biomorph's seed.

visuals.title: Ideal Triangles in the Poincaré disc
visuals.description:
When using the Poincaré disc model for hyperbolic geometry, the hyperbolic universe is inside a circle. The circle itself is at infinity. A triangle inside the circle will always have angle sum < 180 degrees. As the vertices of a triangle approach the circle, the angle sum tends to 0, and the hyperbolic perimeter tends to infinity. The limiting triangle is called an ideal triangle. The hyperbolic area of an ideal triangle is always pi. All triangles in the animation have the same hyperbolic area. 

The animation is used on http://www.malinc.se/math/noneuclidean/mainen.php

visuals.title: Continuity of Bézier splines
visuals.description:
Move the points to make the green curve continuous! 
Move the points to make the blue curve continuous! (you probably ruin the continuity of the green curve)
Hide the velocity and acceleration vectors and show the mirror points! 
When C2 lies on the grey mirror point C1', the velocity is continuous. 
When the yellow mirror points C0' and C3' coincide, the acceleration is continuous. 
Lock C2 and C3 to an A-shape! Move the other points!

visuals.title: Fluid Simulation + Momentum Transfer + Electrostatic Force
visuals.description:
Mouse-interactive fluid simulation with particles.
The fluid simulation is solved on a 16x16 cell grid.
Using Verlet integration for the particle update.
Every particle has an electric charge and two of them have a static value. When any two  particles collide, they equally share it. The border is the electric ground. There's a nonlinear friction and on every collision there's a tiny amount of 1% energy lost, so its passive state approaches a global lower limit energy.
So far, the binding of the forces is one-way only and the particle motion doesn't add to the fluid simulation.
Have fun!

visuals.title: Ideal Triangles in the Poincaré disc
visuals.description:
When using the Poincaré disc model for hyperbolic geometry, the hyperbolic universe is inside a circle. The circle itself is at infinity. A triangle inside the circle will always have angle sum < 180 degrees. As the vertices of a triangle approach the circle, the angle sum tends to 0, and the hyperbolic perimeter tends to infinity. The limiting triangle is called an ideal triangle. The hyperbolic area of an ideal triangle is always pi. All triangles in the animation have the same hyperbolic area. 

The animation is used on http://www.malinc.se/math/noneuclidean/mainen.php

visuals.title: Poincare Hyperbolic Disk Tiling
visuals.description: This sketch illustrates an algorithm for drawing checkered patterns on the the Poincare disk. The Poincare disk is a model of hyperbolic geometry. The pattern is defined by reflections in the circles shown. For each point we check weather it is inside any of the circles. If not, it must be in that triangular space in the middle,  the only bit thats not inside any of the circles. So we draw that pixel white. Otherwise we repeatedly “reflect” the point until it finds its way to the middle triangle. We then colour it depending on weather it took an even or odd number of reflections.
visuals.instructions: Click on any point to see its orbit to the centre under multiple reflections.

visuals.title: Optical Illusion #5 (Hering Illusion)
visuals.description:
The red lines are straight but appear to be bent.

Explanation by livescience.com:
"Evolution has seen to it that geometric drawings like this elicit in us premonitions of the near future. The converging lines toward a vanishing point (the spokes) are cues that trick our brains into thinking we are moving forward as we would in the real world, where the door frame (a pair of vertical lines) seems to bow out as we move through it and we try to perceive what that world will look like in the next instant."

visuals.title: Práctica 4, olas

Con la tecla W se generan olas simples/direccionales, con R olas radiales y con G olas Gerstner. También se pueden crear olas radiales con el ratón. Con la tecla C se activa/desactiva la visualización de la cuadrícula de su malla. Con la tecla T se activa/desactiva la textura. Con la barra espaciadora se vuelve al mar en calma. Debido a un bug de Processing.js, la iluminación no es correcta. Vídeo: https://youtu.be/qfwevzzHvo8

Left/ Right Arrow = increase / decrease angle
Plus / Minus = add / remove  iteration (don't add too much iterations)

visuals.description:
I loved this one by   Bárbara Almeida.

I changed the mountain range to have 7 ridges instead of 9, I look forward to playing with it.

A mountain range landscape.

She was inspired by lesson 38 of Fun Programming: http://funprogramming.org/38-Animate-the-ocean-surface-using-noise.html     **thanks for the reference!** 

She said "Colors chosen to work on Javascript (the clouds and the sky gradient look different on Java mode). Also, I don't know why, the lerpColor didn't work on Java, it's possible to get the same effect with separated map functions for hue, saturation and brightness though."

visuals.title: abstract01js
visuals.description:
abstract01js is a reworking of an old 2D Processing sketch from 2003, created for for the exhibition Abstraction Now in Vienna.

The 2010 version was recreated using Processing.js for  Aram Bartholl's "Speed Show 4: Super Niche" http://fffff.at/speed-show-4/using Processing.js. It was later featured by Processingjs.org for the 1.0 release.

Another version can be seen here:
http://mariuswatz.com/works/abstract01js/

visuals.description: The FitnessGram Pacer Test is a multistage aerobic capacity test that progressively gets more difficult as it continues. The 20 meter pacer test will begin in 30 seconds. Line up at the start. The running speed starts slowly but gets faster each minute after you hear this signal bodeboop. A sing lap should be completed every time you hear this sound. ding Remember to run in a straight line and run as long as possible. The second time you fail to complete a lap before the sound, your test is over. The test will begin on the word start. On your mark. Get ready!… Start.

visuals.title: Circulate
visuals.description: Controls: Mouse pressed stops the lines from spiraling inward, and stops showing their paths. Mouse not pressed sends the lines spiraling inward. At first let the mouse hold still in the center for a few seconds, then start. Also try holding down the mouse and moving it around the screen a bit, and then releasing the mouse and hold it perfectly still, watching what happens. The code is relatively easy to figure out, it's a particle system. Enjoy.

visuals.title: Noise flow field painter
visuals.description:
*It may need a moment to load*

Paints an image with strokes that are rotated by a flow field driven from noise.

If you want to try it on your own image you need to drag and drop an image in the sketch's files tab. Then add your image's file name to the variable imgNames (it's near the top). It doesn't capture details very well so close ups work best.

Controls:
  - Click to change to the next image.
  - Press any key to save the canvas to a jpg.
visuals.instructions: Click for the next image, press a key to save a jpg.

visuals.title: abstract01js
visuals.description:
abstract01js is a reworking of an old 2D Processing sketch from 2003, created for for the exhibition Abstraction Now in Vienna.

The 2010 version was recreated using Processing.js for  Aram Bartholl's "Speed Show 4: Super Niche" http://fffff.at/speed-show-4/using Processing.js. It was later featured by Processingjs.org for the 1.0 release.

Another version can be seen here:
http://mariuswatz.com/works/abstract01js/

visuals.title: Ripples
visuals.description:
A playground of ripples.
This sketch is written in ES6 syntax and requires a CPU with good single core performance. Visuals are adjusted based on performance.
Assignment for NYU Shanghai Interactive Media Arts Nature of Code class.

Some optimizations after 11/04/2017
visuals.instructions: Move / drag mouse, SPACE key for random generation, 'i' for FPS info, 'r' for displaying the ripples.

visuals.title: Pendulum Wave Effect
visuals.description:
Each white circle represents the bob of a pendulum. The pendulums oscillate with frequencies of 1x, 2x, 3x, ... , 20x. Lines connect the circles and make interesting patterns.

'Q' switches between Sines and Cosines.
'D' shows/hides the debug info.

This sketch generates a semi-random image in the style of painter Piet Mondrian.

Comments and criticisms are welcome. I'm pretty new to programming, so I wanted to try something that would be a challenge for a newbie.

visuals.title: My Sketch
visuals.description: delta_theta (blue) compard to cos() (red). The derivative of sin() is cos(), but it's interesting how different (yet similar) the approximation is. Of course, cos() is only applicable to this specific sketch - if applying it to something like perlin noise, I would have to use delta_theta.

visuals.title: The Sobel Op
visuals.description: Exploring the sobel operator. Slider doesn't do anything, will probably come back to this in the future.

visuals.title: Visualizing Vector Addition
visuals.description: Back in my first year of calc, I learned about vectors; when added up, vectors will always reach the same "destination", no matter the order. This sketch was my attempt to visualize that.
visuals.instructions:
Click on the dots inside the graph to change the direction and length of each vector. 
"+" and "-" to add or drop vectors
